title: Language Development and Emergent Literacy: Birth-5
subject: Early Learning Standards (2016-)

D690F644CBD74B3EAB08F000BAECDE92.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds:  Begin to copy or write their own name

6FA4782BB11442F68F0EECCF5A898820.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Engage in writing using letter-like symbols to make letters or words

6C6120DBE40F49D2BB4E281436B9375A.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Use scribbles, shapes, pictures, or dictation to represent thoughts or ideas

FD39468ACED04DB7879F633799A0CD9F.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Understand that writing is a way of communicating

445CB9170C9748649D5527076ACCA011.description:
Three Years: Begin to differentiate between
drawing and writing, and their
scribbles may look more like
writing (E.g. After painting
a picture, 3-year-old Isaiah
makes a series of vertical
lines, representing his name.)

1E30013C269F4A6E849BFB94EC1DA2D6.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Use their increased fine motor
control to control the size and
shape of their scribbles

0768CA7B3E2E48B2916C5CCC1A103DB8.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Scribble and draw and see
these as the same

EABB9522DC3346CE8B472F9A2C7584FF.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Gain more control over the kinds
of marks they make (lines vs.
circular marks)

92685F7B71C149B7BCE0DCBB91F439DB.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Use writing tools (crayons,
markers, pens) and notice that
they can make marks with these
utensils

BC49E9A5D5524EC99EFD248CA7F021C3.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Note: Children at this age are
not aware of writing.

66E50ED6430F4C769662FC23BE76B334.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds:  Understand that specific symbols are used to communicate in writing

808D07E1FDBD469D98616E2B75CD29D9.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Begin to associate sounds with words or letters

5D4D929CADF146299E28F6FDC92B0FDF.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Recognize some letters in the alphabet, especially those in their own name
(E.g. While putting her things away in her cubby, 4-year-old Azlyn notices other
children’s names on their cubbies. She exclaims,“Hey, Autumn starts the same
as me!”)

1F44D9DB1CC64AEF8A4BB75EA4E78F4F.description:
Three Years: Begin to recognize their own
name and may notice words
that start with the same letter
as their own name

F0EB3AA61B224416B75582AB3E7AF368.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Point to print and ask, “What
does that say?” or ask
someone to write for them

11E757CC8FF845F29671513F90675D4E.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Recognize that print and
numerals are symbols that
convey meaning (E.g. Colin, age
2, points to the bottom of his
painting on his classroom wall
and says, “There’s my name.”)

DE8FE0D6515F46269770AA2F9726881A.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Can show awareness of and
recognize some print in the
environment

6CBC0CC9109948878F4C6FFB4CEE9561.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: May begin to recognize that
labels convey meaning (E.g.
Jared sees a box of cheerios
and says, “Oh, Oh!”)

929BF30AF2EA4578A8D88DEDE602F5CB.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Note: Children at this age are
not aware of print as being
distinct from anything else in
their environment.

BFAED2C31E43444989665D12011C4888.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Understand that print carries a message

54B08BFE6A6B4825924B1AC2EDD254D0.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Identify parts of books such as cover, first page, and title

8C1B8021CDD64174A9607E2704649095.description:
Three Years: Understand proper handling of
books to avoid damage and
help repair books, with adult
support

5F2EDBF0FE474F27856C9B128E0389C5.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Can turn the book to the first
page for an adult to begin
reading and close the book and
say, “The end”

B4CA15A0053B435EB7E1E13A462EEF42.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Can identify the front of the book
and use clues on the cover to
select a book (E.g. Using the
cover of the book as a clue,
Charna, 28 months, picks up
The Itsy Bitsy Spider and says to
her mother, “Spider book.”)

279FB439154B4ABB8E0A7A9E78D2D047.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Hold the book properly and
turn pages, sometimes several
at a time

711FDBC6ECD54A04924042333D02A10A.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Look at pictures in books, but
often treat books like other toys
and objects in the environment

A6E57F483F2848BB871B9E3227DB5FCC.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Treat books as any other object
by exploring with hands and
mouth (E.g. 5- month-old Colby
grabs a board book and puts it
to his mouth to chew on it.)

FA375148188142278B091A4AB5A6300F.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Can distinguish the beginning sounds of some words

BE9DC6E6C862455F860E477FFBD0D3DA.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Play with sounds of spoken language including letter sounds, rhymes, and words
(E.g. Ray says, “My name rhymes with play.”)

1C405AF63DFA40409B281ADF243E7FC0.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Listen to and recognize different sounds in rhymes, songs, and familiar words
(E.g. When the teacher sings, “Willaby wallaby Wecca an elephant sat on...”,
Becca shouts, “Becca!”)

7B5D101E855E46D5BBA1873A15115A18.description:
Three Years: Enjoy playing with the sounds
of language (E.g. Claire
laughs loudly when her friend
calls her Clairey Berry.)

059F35F1D94D47BB8CA201C03B6EC7C2.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Participate in chants and songs
and books that rhyme

ECF65E3E70DC48DB91B3CD459B7C5B75.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Enjoy chants and songs and
books that rhyme

C4DE4DFB72CB4F959614216161817218.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Enjoy chants and songs and
books that rhyme

63299A24932440A796673F700EDB3395.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Recognize and react to the
sounds of language and can
discriminate between nonspeech environmental sounds
(E.g. Jamie continues playing
when he hears the refrigerator
door open, but stops when he
hears a jar being opened.)

1E773C6B39824AF79320DB6A4EF81FC2.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Respond to sounds and words
heard often

E60933D242F8427CA73E674D66CFB612.description:
Phonological
awareness
(which refers to
understanding the
sound structure
of language
such as sounds,
rhymes, syllables,
and words)*

96C50F9F7D2C41D19C321DAF6CEEA0FC.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Request or respond to informational books on favorite topics

C1D41E05D605497D9A92ED28E98AB312.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Select favorite books, authors, or illustrators

7DBFBAFD25024CCAB879D053DBAB4334.description:
Three Years: Say what they like about a
favorite book

A7A95A66BD694ACCAFB4AA5C7F3CA762.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Ask for familiar books to be
read in exactly the same way
each time and know when
sections are being skipped

D5A9AADDF6744EC784BFA9EFFAEA2760.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: May ask an adult to read the
same book repeatedly

C608552A197947D3BB1813065833617F.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Name and/or ask for favorite
book and may show preference
for books on certain topics

0BC2E29613D4400F9470369B6BADBEA9.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Bring a book to an adult to be
read to and/or respond positively
to an adult’s offer to read

AF5023C1140F4F9FB0F3D284A431EEFD.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Show enjoyment at being
read to through vocalizing,
eye contact, and movement
(E.g. 8-month-old Sophia
squeals in delight when
her mother reads Ten Little
Fingers and Ten Little Toes.)

1A502B0E9B64429A8FE3EDEDC17C0407.description:
Interest in and
appreciation of
reading*

294AC1C709E34C02B43D256700F66C97.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Retell information from a book (E.g. 5 year old Mac tells his Papa that
Tyrannosaurus Rex runs as fast as a horse.)

2778C42A379F420D97E68B6524B49C72.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Use their own words to retell a simple familiar story while looking at a book

4EC5A49B379C41848589AFDBD81A2FD3.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Represent stories told or read aloud through a variety of media or in play

75404329175D45C49949E896A6B2422D.description:
Three Years: Can ask and answer simple
questions about the story

00F35D1B6A944DEE9E7658532D960C6B.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Ask for familiar books to be
read in exactly the same way
each time and know when
sections are being skipped

ED6183B665AF488F9787A8A67D95666A.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Identify with a particular
character or scene (E.g. When
listening to the book, Where’s
My Teddy Said Eddie, Zaviel,
25 months, makes a scared
face, identifying with the little
boy in the woods.)

12D7FEB77A484E87A91855B75769BFEC.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Point to and vocalize about an
illustration or imitate an action
seen in a picture (E.g. 18-
month-old Angelique imitates the
jumping action of the frog when
being read, Jump Frog Jump.)

AFC9588FBE0F42D28D9F7EADD41DEF00.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: May focus on certain elements
in the illustrations, but often
skip pages or focus on a
particular page

1BF8BF3C83BB4B64A0E0DDFC0C890C0B.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Enjoy hearing a book
being read and looking at
the pictures, but do not
understand the sequence of
the story

CD2A7C4C60334D719D43D63AD4A11FB5.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Tell their own stories

847C6BBA863D4669AFAD5D8E1E5840A7.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Guess what will happen next in a story using pictures as a guide

79F12EDB09784DF88195BB99F9067082.description:
Three Years: Relate or retell stories with
more parts

A3EF75FD4BE44F33BF0452F8DDFFAE84.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Can react to dramatic elements
of a story and may respond
with predictions when asked,
“What will happen next?”
(E.g. Addison, 33 months, is
able to predict what is hidden
under the flap on a page of a
familiar book.)

8E38B1F15B5A460DB6790564D57237EB.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: May relay or retell simple
stories

973B30A067024B62AC16CB6C9FCD8825.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Can recognize that a story is
beginning from a clue such as
‘Once upon a time’

16EF9A61065C42A2A0A99CD837852D01.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Participate in book reading
activities (E.g. Brandon, 15
months, makes a shhh sound
and puts his finger on his lips
at the appropriate time when
reading The Napping House.)

5FA1FF9CCF3040EF9AF6925279230FCC.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Look at the face of an adult
describing the sequence of
what will happen next (E.g.
5-month-old Nate stares
intently at his father’s face
when he describes how he will
change Nate’s diaper.)

C0DE9FF97E494BEA9568418A761F296D.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Make connections between a book or story to personal experiences
(E.g. Irena points to a picture of a dog and says, “I have a dog like this,
only bigger and my dog never chews shoes”.)

095E8DF68DC74FBF8B697F680D878255.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds:  Ask questions about a book or story

E0A94D797A5A425486EE80ACC1F150C9.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Respond to adult questions about a book or story

FD7DF5E426BC43BBB8CB69C5823B1BDB.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Ask for a story to be read and respond to stories told or read aloud

34D423CA1F834AE0A74164FEEA0643EB.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Learn new information from books being read to them

52FC60EB46FD4068868AD8FB855DAB00.description:
Three Years: May describe what’s
happening in the pictures
while turning the pages in a
familiar book

B3608036D99648B7BAD92FE323589841.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Enjoy being read to and looking
at books independently; May
say familiar words and phrases
while looking at the appropriate
page (E.g. Kali, 33 months,
sings along to the repetitious
book, Brown Bear, Brown Bear,
as her teacher reads it to her.)

B432C2367FAE4533BF36F82042CC7874.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: While being read to, point to
and comment on illustrations
and repeat or anticipate familiar
words or phrases in the text

4718E6E69D99413AB5E7A56696B3623D.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: May show preferences for
specific books and turn pages at
the appropriate time with adult
assistance

C34853A316EA45EB8208EB24898657F4.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Enjoy being read to and may
seek opportunities to be read to
and to interact with books

AD21EF1F36804179A41D069097D99D69.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Focus on picture books while
an adult is reading to them
(E.g. 6-month-old Alisha
sits on her mother’s lap and
looks and pats her hand on
the book that her mother is
reading.)

8C2C3ABA7B3B4546A2E0070572B24A74.description:
Participation in
language and
literacy activities*

AD79615E61FE4F04B4016F3D11E2E124.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Tell stories with multiple characters and events

D7F646239E63455A923012A62721A8D8.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds:  Ask questions and initiate and respond in conversations with others

52D89275CC1B49EA8EE6847E48D713D0.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Use language for a variety of purposes, including communicating information
(E.g. 5-year-old Sean shows his friends his new race car and they ask him
questions about it and tell him stories about theirs.)

15C99B88088E47269DD2C1D6014F42C4.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Speak clearly enough to be understood

0438391446ED43FC84366DFD9678AED8.description:
Three Years: Can relate a simple story
(E.g. When asked about her
day, Rhianna says, “I went
out on the playground and
it was so icy and I fell and
I cried and cried and my
teacher helped me.”)

F3C8A2C6503147318A236D072CEF1CF8.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Use more connecting words,
such as “and” or “then”

919F3534865641529E1D86D859C5EBDB.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Use words and some common
rules of speech to express their
ideas and thoughts (E.g. Margie
exclaims, “I climbed up stairs!”)

90560F3117534D01B39E6D89A015B8FC.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Begin to use words to
communicate and may combine
two to three words to form short
phrases or sentences

9460B57EC699498689B849A7DD4A6AA7.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Move from imitating single
words to beginning to use single
words to communicate

F12A5C54640C477C8170A3490FD9D932.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Begin vocalizing using a
variety of sounds (E.g. Stan
uses different types of cries to
communicate different needs.)

E85E96DC1CDE49029B9624BC3229FC4C.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Use words and phrases learned through conversations and being read to
(E.g. 4-year-old Hazel says, “The end”, when she finishes her snack.)

A03DDA046DD74A5E9D07F5825474AA0A.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Use increasingly complex and varied vocabulary and language

34FCF1439FE64E858A385561ACC222C5.description:
Three Years: Continue to build their
vocabulary including more
descriptive words

4520EB59426E45A586799D1074EFFB53.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Correctly use a growing number
of vocabulary words and show
interest in new words (E.g. Liam
knows that fast, quick, and
speedy mean the same thing.)

F5C300D1410D47E5B0F57617E9F72D7A.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Demonstrate a burst of new
vocabulary words, which they
may or may not use correctly

30BED481447B480CBA719A578E144A52.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Combine two words to express
wants or needs (E.g. As Harper
walks to the car she says, “Car
go.”)

C9AD0864B6ED4DDCA22DF705119423B2.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Produce their first word and
may have a vocabulary of up to
15 words

D786A146DA6243AA80B4509DAAF2F906.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: At this age children are not
communicating with words

95CA2E04E0114D0A936108E3FCEC0E24.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: With adult support, can take turns in conversations and group discussions

F14FF79D981F433C9C3B527CDFC1EA4F.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Use language according to rules appropriate for the cultural context (may need
adult help in recognizing appropriate cultural context) (E.g. 4-year-old Savannah
asks her peer, “Can I please have the purple crayon?”)

4E7387A746114662A0A33F1B60EDAFFF.description:
Three Years: Begin to understand the rules
for communication in different
situations (E.g. Charlie
whispers when dad explains
that he needs to use a quiet
voice when visiting grandpa in
the hospital.)

F688A62FCB774914B8DDF1D48DB9D5F9.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Can participate in simple
conversational exchanges,
usually with adults

83CDB18D8A0D4403A6B3644707448ED1.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Use language for a variety of
functions

79FFD1EDA4C04B2D9ACB062ED372257B.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Convey a variety of meanings
through simple vocabulary
(E.g. Jeff says “milk,” which
can mean, “I want milk,” “I’m
finished drinking milk,” or “I
spilled my milk.”)

5367F77CD69447EE9441AFBBDA297FAE.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Begin to use single words to
communicate

5EAA943357E8495688957BBCF194FFA9.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Use sounds to get adult
attention and to engage adults

5DD6E4783AC248D28F640FA385BEA253.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Communicate needs, wants, or thoughts using nonverbal gestures, actions, or
expressions (E.g. 5-year-old Devin points to the block area when he is asked
what he wants to do next.)

AC289692D8B241A08D40FD26D43DAD5C.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Understand non-verbal cues

C049F90BAB744D1CBBED995306A6F2D2.description:
Three Years: Notice other children’s body
language and try to interpret it

41775E3AD5D44B6291FC857358953639.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Begin to understand other
children’s nonverbal social cues

803BD196D82041E9A0B5CD040AF679BE.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Use gestures to augment what
they are trying to communicate
with words (E.g. Destiny shakes
her head emphatically as she
says, “No, no, no.”)

9FE47C1B7C30439EA7AA5138BB94A208.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: Understand others’ nonverbal
symbolic cues such as nodding
for yes or shaking head for no

F2367465B64846AC89D21981F8B8FAA4.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Communicate using consistent
sounds, gestures, and facial
expressions

057EFB575747472DAB28D0ABCE186ACA.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Use various sounds and
movements to communicate

B4A97F3FE440476CA70BF10E9C3DF7D2.description:
Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Follow instructions that include a two or three step sequence of actions such as
setting up a game or following a recipe

DA337E8FDB564B90AB4181609FA93814.description: Four- and Five-Year-Olds: Listen with understanding to stories, directions, and conversations

EA09357D6E21495E92A83FEFE80B143F.description:
Three Years: Show awareness of others’
comments or statements that
have to do with them (E.g.
Milo shouts, “Don’t want
to go to the doctor!” after
overhearing his parents talk
about his illness.)

F77D728C46AF4E8C8C456E96EA60D31C.description:
Thirty Months to
Three Years: Respond to simple questions

B4E76B50373240A282B2DCC401D12AE6.description:
Twenty-Four to
Thirty Months: Show by their actions that they
understand simple one-step
directions (E.g. When her
teacher says, “Put on your
coat,” Doretta picks up her
coat and puts her hand in the
sleeve.)

DAFF5A6A3BE4461AA4E14B054C1C07A7.description:
Eighteen to
Twenty-Four Months: May show by their actions
understanding of simple
statements (E.g. Blaine sits
down at the table when his
teacher says, “It’s time to eat.”)

97E8F1DC3ECA4350A767BA155D3ADC05.description:
Nine Months to
Eighteen Months
: Demonstrate their understanding
of others’ speech through their
actions, such as responding
physically to simple requests
(E.g. Joshua, 15 months, smiles
when his father says, “Smile at
Daddy.”)

5787F966607F4605873E80B689E17C6A.description:
Birth to
Nine Months: Show interest in the speech
of others and prefer familiar
voices
